author: Paul Gilder
title: Bourse hits skids as engine groans
text:
AUSTRALIA’S benchmark share index has sunk below 5000 points for the first time in two years as skittish investors retreat amid evidence of a deeper slowdown in China’s manufacturing heartland.
Fear and loathing were again the headline acts on the ASX 200 yesterday after it had enjoyed a patch of blue sky on Tuesday.
At the close, the index had lost 2.1 per cent to close at 4998.1 points — its lowest mark since July 19, 2013.
The plunge was bigger than Monday’s fall, which was a reaction to the US Federal Reserve’s decision late last week to keep interest rates on hold as global growth concerns lingered.
It means that, setting aside Tuesday’s brief respite, Australia’s listed companies have shed about $60 billion in value since the Fed’s call.
China provided the trigger yesterday, with a preliminary measure of manufacturing activity falling to a fresh six-and-a-half year low of 47 points in September, with figures below 50 indicating an industry in contraction.
The index, published by Beijing-based media company Caixin, revealed factory output, export orders and employment were shrinking at a faster pace than a month earlier.
CMC chief market strategist Michael McCarthy said that given the Fed’s “laundry list” of concerns, ongoing weakness in China was the last thing traders wanted to see.
“There’s a lot of pressure in a fragile trading environment and those Chinese numbers have just been the catalyst. It wasn’t just Australia, it was all across the region,” Mr McCarthy said. Japan’s Nikkei index gave up 2 per cent and Hong Kong’s Hang Seng 2.3 per cent.
At home, the materials sector led the bourse lower, joined by energy stocks after oil prices soured. Miner South32 was down 5.7 per cent, while parent BHP Billiton shed 4.4 per cent.
Mr McCarthy said while 5000 was a “nice round number”, it wasn’t a key resistance level.
